div.head: The Hours: Virginia Woolf’s Modern Echo
div.p: The film The Hours (2002) interweaves three parallel narratives to explore the enduring legacy of Virginia Woolf’s writing. One storyline portrays Woolf herself—struggling to compose Mrs. Dalloway—played by Nicole Kidman. The second follows Laura Brown (played by Julianne Moore), a 1950s housewife who reads Woolf’s novel and contemplates her own life choices. The third narrative centers on Clarissa Vaughan (played by Meryl Streep), a contemporary New Yorker planning a party for her friend Richard, a poet dying of suicide. The film's title refers to the concept of time and the hours that shape our lives, echoing Woolf's exploration of consciousness and the passage of time in her own work.
